BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs are to be evaluated critically. Gliding avalanches are also to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The extensive wind slabs of the last few days must be evaluated with care and prudence on northwest to north to east facing aspects above approximately 2400 m. Avalanches can in some places be released by a single winter sport participant and reach dangerously large size. At elevated altitudes the likelihood of avalanches being released is greater. The clearly visible wind slabs are to be avoided whenever possible.
Weak layers in the lower part of the snowpack can still be released in very isolated cases on steep, rather lightly snow-covered shady slopes.

On extremely steep sunny slopes medium-sized loose snow avalanches are to be expected as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
In addition a substantial danger of gliding avalanches exists. This applies on steep grassy slopes in all aspects in particular below approximately 2400 m. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The weather will be very mild. The weather conditions will bring about a slow stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations. As a consequence of a moderate to strong wind from westerly directions, further wind slabs will form adjacent to ridgelines. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are in some cases prone to triggering in particular on northwest to north to east facing aspects above approximately 2400 m. Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist in the bottom section of the old snowpack on steep, rather lightly snow-covered shady slopes.

The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. The snowpack will be moist below approximately 2000 m. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise to gradual moistening of the snowpack on steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of warming there will be an additional decrease in the danger of dry avalanches. Fresh wind slabs are in some cases prone to triggering in particular on very steep shady slopes at elevated altitudes. Gliding avalanches are to be expected. As a consequence of solar radiation individual moist loose snow avalanches are possible.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of new snow and northwesterly wind, further wind slabs formed in the last few days in places that are protected from the wind. The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. Wind slabs are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. They are covered with new snow and are difficult to recognise. In particular on very steep shady slopes the avalanches can be released in the various wind slab layers and reach large size.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 10 to 40 cm of snow has fallen since Friday above approximately 2000 m. The wind was strong. The wind has transported the new snow significantly. The more recent wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust in particular on sunny slopes below approximately 2400 m. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a strong to storm force wind, sometimes deep wind slabs formed in the last few days in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
In particular at a distance from ridgelines places that are protected from the wind: More recent wind slabs are easy to recognise but can in some cases be released easily. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible in isolated cases. Caution is to be exercised on steep shady slopes. At transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack the likelihood of avalanches being released is greater.
The weather will be mild. Small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day. This applies in particular in steep rocky terrain, and at the base of rock walls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind. More recent wind slabs are to be found also areas not adjacent to ridgelines.
Over a wide area there is more snow than usual.
As a consequence of the strong to storm force wind, a crust formed on the surface during the last few days.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The conditions are sometimes critical for backcountry touring and other off-piste activities outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released easily or naturally in all aspects, especially in areas close to the tree line and above the tree line. Wind slabs can especially at their margins be released, even by a single winter sport participant. Avalanches can also penetrate deep layers and reach medium size.
Caution is to be exercised in particular at the base of rock walls, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack can indicate the danger. The snowpack will be generally subject to considerable local variations.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding avalanches require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs are prone to triggering above approximately 2400 m. They can in some places be released by a single winter sport participant. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas, as well as in gullies and bowls. At elevated altitudes the likelihood of avalanches is a little higher. Avalanches can in very isolated cases penetrate deep layers and reach large size, especially on steep, rather lightly snow-covered shady slopes.

As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation more frequent loose snow avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses. In addition a certain danger of gliding avalanches exists, especially on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2400 m in the regions with a lot of snow. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 15 to 30 cm of snow, and up to 50 cm in some localities, fell on Friday above approximately 1500 m. The storm force wind has transported the new snow significantly. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.

Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.

Low and intermediate altitudes: The snowpack is moist.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Slight decrease in danger of dry avalanches. Fresh wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence. Gliding avalanches require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The more recent wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In particular adjacent to ridgelines in all aspects: The strong wind has transported the fresh and old snow significantly.
In particular transitions into gullies and bowls places that are protected from the wind: Fresh wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, especially on very steep shady slopes.
The weather will be mild. Mostly small moist and wet avalanches are possible. This applies in particular in steep rocky terrain, and at the base of rock walls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind. More recent wind slabs are to be found also areas not adjacent to ridgelines. In particular in the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 1 (low) a little snow is lying in all altitude zones.
As a consequence of the strong to storm force wind, a crust formed on the surface during the last few days.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The storm force wind has transported the fresh and old snow significantly. The fresh and older wind slabs represent the main danger. Avalanches can in isolated cases be released by small loads and reach medium size. This applies in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Between approximately 2400 and 3000 m the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to consolidation of the snowpack at low and intermediate altitudes. At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger. The weather will be mild.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The more recent wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on shady slopes above approximately 1800 m. In particular on steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain small and medium-sized slab avalanches are possible. At elevated altitudes the avalanche prone locations are more widespread.
Several small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust and will soften during the day. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. In particular at low and intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the sometimes large wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence especially on north to northeast to northwest facing aspects. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in north to northeast to northwest facing aspects and on wind-loaded slopes. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack serve as an alarm indicating the danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack remains unfavourable in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs are to be evaluated critically.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh wind slabs can be released easily. or in isolated cases naturally,, especially on steep shady slopes in areas close to the tree line, as well as above the tree line. They can especially at their margins be released very easily. Caution is to be exercised in particular at the base of rock walls, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Avalanches can reach medium size.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. The snowpack will be generally subject to considerable local variations.
Low and intermediate altitudes: Towards its base, the snowpack is moist. The surface of the snowpack will soften during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Slight increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation, in particular on steep sunny slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released easily in some places, especially on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. At elevated altitudes the likelihood of avalanches is a little higher. Avalanches can reach medium size.

On rocky sunny slopes small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Friday above approximately 1500 m. As a consequence of a sometimes storm force wind, clearly visible wind slabs formed in the last few days. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on near-ridge shady slopes at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted.

Low and intermediate altitudes: The snowpack is moist.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wind slabs represent the main danger. The meteorological conditions will facilitate a slow change towards better conditions.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In all aspects hardly any snow is lying.
Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
Hardly any small avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming. Very isolated avalanche prone locations are to be found at high altitude and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The more recent wind slabs are to be found in gullies and bowls and at high altitudes. They are very small. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to softening of the old snowpack. Backcountry touring calls for caution and restraint. There is a danger of falling on the icy crust.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The older wind slabs are easy to recognise and unlikely to be released now.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The surface of the snowpack will soften during the day. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations. Hardly any snow is lying above approximately 1600 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In all aspects hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In these regions from a snow sport perspective, insufficient snow is lying.
Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
The fresh wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. The surface of the snowpack will soften during the day. In particular at low and intermediate altitudes a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will persist. As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase on steep sunny slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be well bonded at low altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust and will soften during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack is well consolidated.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution, especially along the border with France.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads, at elevated altitudes. The avalanche prone locations are rather rare. These avalanche prone locations are to be found at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack above approximately 2400 m.
In some places wind slabs are lying on an icy crust. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 2400 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. At higher altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
